assumedPriorKnowledge: Fluent simplification of fractions to lowest terms
Confident multiplication and division of decimals
Conversion between common units (km/m, hr/min, etc.)
designPrinciples: Emphasis on multiplicative reasoning over additive
Transfer across contexts (ratios, rates, scales, speed)

curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Solve problems involving rates and ratios with and without digital technologies

keyConcepts.name: Ratio as multiplicative comparison
keyConcepts.description: Understanding ratio as comparing quantities multiplicatively, not additively. If a:b = 2:3, then a is 2/3 of b, not 'one less than b'.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Strong students should recognise ratio as a function: a = (2/3)b

keyConcepts.name: Equivalent ratios and scaling
keyConcepts.description: Generating equivalent ratios by multiplying/dividing both parts by the same factor. Recognising the constant multiplicative relationship.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Connect to linear proportionality: y = kx where k is the constant of proportionality

keyConcepts.name: Dividing quantities in given ratios
keyConcepts.description: Partitioning a total into parts with a given ratio. Understanding 'total parts' approach and algebraic method.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Extend to three-part ratios and finding one part given another

keyConcepts.name: Rate as ratio of different units
keyConcepts.description: Understanding rate as comparison of quantities with different units. Recognising that rates create a multiplicative relationship between two variables.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Rate as the gradient of a linear relationship through origin

keyConcepts.name: Unit rate and its applications
keyConcepts.description: Converting to 'per one' form for comparison. Understanding unit rate as the constant of proportionality. Applying to best buy problems.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Unit rate enables direct comparison; $/kg, km/hr are unit rates

keyConcepts.name: Speed, distance, time relationships
keyConcepts.description: Flexible use of s = d/t in all three arrangements. Understanding speed as a rate. Converting units within problems.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Multiple-leg journey problems; distinguishing instantaneous vs average speed

keyConcepts.name: Average speed for multi-leg journeys
keyConcepts.description: Calculating average speed as total distance ÷ total time, NOT the arithmetic mean of individual speeds. Handling different distances or times.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Classic misconception target: 60km at 30km/h + 60km at 60km/h ≠ average 45km/h

keyConcepts.name: Scale drawings and maps
keyConcepts.description: Interpreting scale ratios (1:50000). Converting between scale and actual measurements in both directions. Using scale bars.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Area scales as square of length scale; volume scales as cube

keyConcepts.name: Rate conversion between units
keyConcepts.description: Converting rates to different units (km/h to m/s, $/kg to $/100g). Understanding dimensional analysis approach.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Systematic approach: multiply by conversion factors as fractions

keyConcepts.name: Comparing and combining rates
keyConcepts.description: Comparing rates with different units by converting to common form. Combining rates in work problems (pipes filling tanks, workers completing jobs).
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Preview of inverse proportionality and combined rate problems

keyConcepts.name: Proportional reasoning in context
keyConcepts.description: Identifying proportional relationships in real contexts. Setting up and solving proportion equations. Verifying proportionality.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Determine IF relationship is proportional before applying proportional methods

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Using additive rather than multiplicative reasoning for ratios
commonMisconceptions.correction: Ratios compare quantities multiplicatively. If 2:3, then one quantity is 2/3 (or 1.5× or 66.7%) of the other, NOT 'one less'.
commonMisconceptions.source: ScienceDirect - Analysis of proportional reasoning; ERIC EJ1187432
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Ratio is 2:5. To scale up to 4:?, student adds 2 to get 4:7 instead of multiplying to get 4:10
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Use double number lines; emphasise 'times' not 'plus'; verify with multiplication
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Fundamental misconception that persists even in strong students under time pressure

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Averaging speeds arithmetically for multi-leg journeys
commonMisconceptions.correction: Average speed = Total Distance ÷ Total Time. Cannot average speeds directly unless time travelled at each speed is equal.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Travel 60km at 30km/h, then 60km at 60km/h. Student: average = (30+60)/2 = 45km/h. Correct: 120km ÷ 3hrs = 40km/h
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Always calculate total distance and total time separately first; only then divide
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Classic 'trick' problem that catches even mathematically strong students

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Confusing part-part ratio with part-whole fraction
commonMisconceptions.correction: Ratio 2:3 means parts are 2 and 3. Total is 5 parts. Part-whole fractions are 2/5 and 3/5, NOT 2/3 and 3/3.
commonMisconceptions.source: Tandfonline - Misconceptions on part-part-whole proportional relationships
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Boys to girls is 3:5. Student says 3/5 of class are boys. Correct: 3/8 are boys (3 out of 3+5)
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Explicitly distinguish ratio (part:part) from fraction (part/whole); draw bar models
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Linguistic confusion between ratio and fraction terminology

commonMisconceptions.correction: Rates must be in same units to compare directly. Convert to common unit or unit rate before comparison.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: $3.50 for 500g vs $6.80/kg - student compares 3.50 to 6.80 directly
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Always convert to same units first; unit rates (per 1 unit) make comparison easiest
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Rushing through best buy problems without unit conversion

commonMisconceptions.correction: Scale 1:1000 means 1cm on map = 1000cm real. Map to real: MULTIPLY by scale factor. Real to map: DIVIDE.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Scale 1:50000. Distance on map is 3cm. Student divides: 3÷50000. Correct: 3×50000 = 150000cm = 1.5km
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Ask 'Is real bigger or smaller than map?' Real is bigger, so multiply; verbal logic check
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Procedural confusion about when to multiply vs divide

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Converting time decimals incorrectly (0.5 hours = 50 minutes)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Decimal hours convert to minutes by ×60. 0.5 hours = 30 minutes. 0.3 hours = 18 minutes, NOT 30 minutes.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 12 miles at 40mph: 12÷40 = 0.3 hours. Student interprets as 30 minutes instead of 18 minutes
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Explicitly teach decimal-to-time conversion; use fractions (0.3 = 3/10 = 18/60)

commonMisconceptions.correction: Not all relationships are proportional. Proportional relationships pass through origin and have constant rate of change.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Taxi costs $4 flag fall + $2/km. Student treats as proportional: 10km = $20, but correct is $24
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Check: does doubling input double output? Does (0,0) make sense? If no, not proportional
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Over-applying proportional methods to non-proportional situations

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Swapping ratio terms or units when setting up proportions
commonMisconceptions.correction: Corresponding quantities must align in proportions. If comparing apples to oranges, both ratios must have apples first (or both oranges first).
commonMisconceptions.source: ResearchGate - Teacher Knowledge on Ratio Misconceptions
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 3 workers take 12 days. How long for 4 workers? Student sets up 3/12 = 4/x instead of recognising inverse proportion
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Label all quantities; check logical direction (more workers = less time?); verify answer makes sense

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Is the 'family size' really better value? Woolworths shows $/100g - but what if one is $/100mL?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Weetbix 750g for $5.50 vs 1.2kg for $8.40. Convert to $/100g: $0.733 vs $0.70. Larger is better by 3.3c/100g.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: ACCC unit pricing laws; Woolworths, Coles shelf labels; consumer mathematics
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Requires unit conversion and comparison; real consumer decision-making

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Sydney to Melbourne road trip planning
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Google Maps says 9 hours for 878km. But you'll drive faster on highways and slower through towns. What's your real average speed?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Plan: 700km at 100km/h + 178km at 60km/h. Time: 7 + 2.97 = 9.97hrs. Average: 878/9.97 = 88km/h, not (100+60)/2 = 80km/h
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Hume Highway trips; family holiday planning; fuel stop calculations
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Multi-leg journey with different speeds; unit conversions; average speed misconception

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Petrol prices and fuel efficiency comparison
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Your car does 8.5L/100km. Petrol is $1.89/L. Your friend's car does 42mpg (US). Who has the cheaper running cost?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Petrol prices; L/100km vs mpg confusion; comparing car efficiency
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Cross-system unit conversion (metric/imperial); rate comparison; multi-step

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Recipe scaling for different group sizes
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A recipe serves 6 but you're cooking for 15. Some ingredients come in fixed pack sizes. How do you scale up efficiently?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Recipe: 400g pasta, 250g mince, 700mL sauce for 6. For 15: need 2.5× each. Pasta packs are 500g - buy 2 packs (have 1000g, need exactly).
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Home cooking; hospitality studies; practical mathematics
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Scaling with real constraints; rounding decisions with pack sizes

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: House floor plans and room dimensions
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A floor plan has scale 1:100. The bedroom measures 4cm × 3.5cm on paper. Will your queen bed (153cm × 203cm) fit with space around it?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Real room: 4m × 3.5m = 400cm × 350cm. Bed needs ~180cm × 230cm with walking space. Yes, fits with 220cm and 120cm clearance.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Real estate; interior design; moving house; furniture planning
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Scale conversion both directions; practical constraint checking

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Smith averages 61.8 runs per innings. Warner averages 44.3 but scores faster at 4.5 runs per over. Who's the better Test opener?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Different rates measure different things. Run rate (runs/over) vs batting average (runs/dismissal). Both are rates but answer different questions.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Cricket obsession; BBL, Test cricket; sports analytics; AFL stats (disposals/game)
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Understanding what different rates measure; contextual interpretation

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: You have 80GB/month. You've used 23GB in 9 days. At this rate, will you run out before the month ends?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Usage rate: 23GB/9 days = 2.56GB/day. Monthly projection: 2.56 × 30 = 76.7GB. Safe! But if 31-day month: 79.3GB - still safe.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Telstra, Optus, Vodafone plans; data management; teen phone usage
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Rate projection; proportional reasoning; practical decision-making

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: AUD to Japanese Yen is 98.5. You have $2000 AUD. In Tokyo, a meal costs ¥1500. How many meals can you buy?
realWorldPhenomena.context: $2000 × 98.5 = ¥197,000. Meals: 197,000 ÷ 1500 = 131 meals. Rate as multiplier; inverse for reverse conversion.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Japan trips popular; Bali (IDR), NZ (NZD); exchange rates in news
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Exchange rate as ratio; forward and reverse conversion; large numbers

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A marathon is 42.195km. If you run the first half at 5:00/km pace and tire to 5:30/km for the second half, what's your finish time?
realWorldPhenomena.context: First 21.1km at 5:00/km = 105.5 min. Second 21.1km at 5:30/km = 116 min. Total: 221.5 min = 3:41:30. Average pace: 5:15/km.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: City2Surf; parkrun popularity; fitness tracking apps (Strava)
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Pace (min/km) as rate; time arithmetic; average pace calculation

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Work rate problems: painting, building, filling
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: One painter takes 6 hours to paint a room. Another takes 4 hours. Working together, is it (6+4)/2 = 5 hours? Or faster?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Painter A: 1/6 room/hr. Painter B: 1/4 room/hr. Together: 1/6 + 1/4 = 5/12 room/hr. Time: 12/5 = 2.4 hours = 2hrs 24min.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Tradie work; pool filling; project planning; collaborative work
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Combined rates; adding rates not times; fraction arithmetic

scaffoldingSequence.name: Consolidation - Ratio Fluency
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Multiplicative reasoning mastery; equivalent ratios; ratio vs fraction distinction
activities: Speed drill: simplify ratios and generate equivalents
Identify multiplicative relationship in ratio problems
Error analysis: spot additive reasoning mistakes

scaffoldingSequence.name: Core Application - Rates and Unit Rates
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Rate as ratio with units; unit rate for comparison; best buy problems
activities: Convert rates to unit rates for comparison
Best buy problems with unit conversion required

scaffoldingSequence.name: Speed, Distance, Time Mastery
scaffoldingSequence.focus: SDT formula in all arrangements; multi-leg journeys; average speed
activities: Average speed problems (total dist ÷ total time)
Scale drawing problems with unit conversion

scaffoldingSequence.name: Advanced Applications
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Rate conversion; combined rates; proportional reasoning in context
activities: Convert rates between unit systems (km/h to m/s)

scaffoldingSequence.name: Extension - Challenge and Transfer
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Novel contexts; inverse proportion preview; problem creation
activities: Inverse proportion problems (more workers, less time)
Create and solve own rate comparison problem
Analyse whether given scenario is proportional

cognitiveLoadNotes: Ensure multiplicative reasoning is automatic before complex applications
Use worked examples for average speed problems (high misconception area)
Separate unit conversion from rate calculation initially, then combine
Visual representations (double number lines, ratio tables) reduce load
Introduce dimensional analysis as systematic method for conversions
engagementStrategies: Use current Australian prices and contexts (petrol, groceries, data plans)
Counter-intuitive average speed problems create productive struggle
Real decision-making contexts (best buy, trip planning, recipe scaling)
Error analysis: 'Find and explain the mistake' builds metacognition
Sports statistics appeal to competitive and analytical students
motivationFactors: Consumer empowerment: making better purchasing decisions
Travel planning: real-world application for holidays
Financial literacy: exchange rates, data usage, fuel costs

interleaving.rationale: High performers benefit from early interleaving (Rohrer & Taylor). Mix ratio, rate, and speed problems to prevent context-dependent learning.
interleaving.implementation: From Phase 2, every problem set includes at least 3 different contexts. Students must identify problem type before solving.

desirableDifficulties: Unfamiliar unit combinations (not just km/h and $/kg)
Problems requiring rate conversion before comparison
Multi-leg journeys with different distances AND speeds
Non-proportional relationships embedded with proportional ones
Insufficient information problems: identify what's missing

testingEffect.implementation: Weekly cumulative retrieval covering all prior phases
testingEffect.timing: Short diagnostic at start of each session; comprehensive review every 5th session
testingEffect.format: Mix of: rapid calculation, word problem interpretation, error identification, explain-your-reasoning

transferExpectations: Apply ratio/rate reasoning to novel contexts not explicitly taught
Recognise when proportional methods apply vs when they don't
Self-correct using estimation and unit analysis
Explain why additive reasoning fails for ratios

support: Provide ratio table templates for complex problems
Offer unit conversion reference sheet initially
Break multi-step problems into guided sub-steps
Allow calculator for arithmetic to focus on reasoning
extension: Dimensional analysis for complex unit conversions
Create and solve multi-step real-world scenarios
Compare rates involving compound units (kg/m³, kWh)
Rates of change preview (gradient as rate)

summative: Multi-step rate problem requiring unit conversion
Average speed problem for multi-leg journey
Best buy comparison with mixed units
Scale drawing problem with both conversions (map↔real)
successCriteria: Consistently uses multiplicative (not additive) reasoning for ratios
Accurately calculates and compares unit rates
Correctly applies average speed = total distance ÷ total time
Confidently converts between scale and actual measurements
Identifies when proportional methods are appropriate
Verifies answers using estimation and inverse operations
advancedSuccessCriteria: Converts rates between any unit systems using dimensional analysis
Solves combined rate problems (work rate, filling tanks)
Creates and solves novel rate problems for peers
Explains WHY average speed ≠ arithmetic mean of speeds
